name: semanage
desc: The semanage command line is a tool for managing SELinux policies, which can be used to change SELinux security contexts and policies. It allows users to change the SELinux context for files and processes, as well as add, delete, and modify SELinux policy modules.

-a.name: Add or update a SELinux policy module

-b.name: By default, do not recurse into owning directory's subdirectories

-B.name: By default, recurse all owning directory's subdirectories

-D.name: Delete all versions of a SELinux policy module

-e.name: Show file name and full path of SELinux policy module

-f.name: Load SELinux policy module from file

-F.name: Output SELinux policy module into file

-i.name: Install SELinux policy module from file

-n.name: Do not execute changes to SELinux policy module

-N.name: Do not execute changes to SELinux policy module, but allow SELinux policy module to print logs

-R.name: Recurse all owning directory's subdirectories, including mount points

-s.name: Set a new name for SELinux policy module

-S.name: Print size of SELinux policy module

-t.name: Set SELinux security context for a file or process

-x.name: Remove a file from a SELinux policy module

content:
Example

  • Change the SELinux security context of the /var/www directory to httpd_sys_content_t:

    semanage fcontext -a -t httpd_sys_content_t "/var/www(/.*)?"
restorecon -Rv /var/www

  • Change the httpd security context back to default:

    semanage fcontext -d -t httpd_sys_content_t "/var/www(/.*)?"
restorecon -Rv /var/www

  • Enable httpd_can_network_connect permission:

    semanage port -a -t http_port_t -p tcp 8080
semanage port -a -t http_port_t -p tcp 8888
semanage boolean -m httpd_can_network_connect 1

  • Display all installed SELinux modules:

    semanage module -l

  • Install a new SELinux module:

    semanage module -i /root/example.pp

  • Remove SELinux module:

    semanage module -r example

  • List all SELinux users:

    semanage login -l

  • Add a new SELinux user:

    semanage login -a -s user_u -r s0-s0:c0.c1023 example_user

  • Remove a SELinux user:

    semanage login -d example_user
